item.title: Trump Wants Putin Meeting ‘Soon,’ Heads Home From Mideast
item.description: President Donald Trump said he would meet Russian President Vladimir Putin “as soon as we can set it up,” foreclosing an immediate face-to-face encounter aimed at brokering an end to the war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer A Dlouhy

media:content.media:description: President Donald Trump, center, speaks during the US-UAE Investment Forum in Abu Dhabi on May 16. Photographer: Brendan Smialowski/Getty Images

item.title: Israel Alarmed by Trump’s Arms Sales and Deals With Gulf States
item.description: President Donald Trump’s Middle East tour has left Israel apprehensive about a shift in US foreign policy from one rooted in security to a focus on commerce, especially massive arms sales to neighbors that don’t recognize the Jewish state.
item.dc:creator: Galit Altstein, Ethan Bronner

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump reviews the honour guard at the Royal Court in Riyadh on May 13.

item.title: APEC Trade Ministers Agree Statement Without Mentioning Tariffs
item.description: Trade chiefs from some of the world’s biggest economies including the US and China agreed to focus on reforming global trade rules, after reaching an unexpected agreement by ignoring one of their biggest points of difference: tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Yoshiaki Nohara, Soo-Hyang Choi, James Mayger

media:content.media:description: The Taicang Port Area International Container Terminal in Suzhou, China.

item.title: Treasuries, US-Made Japanese Cars Seen as Leverage
item.description: Holding longer-term Treasuries and importing Japanese cars manufactured in the US are among the possible bargaining chips for Tokyo in its talks with Washington over President Donald Trump’s sweeping tariffs, according to the leader of a small but influential opposition party.
item.dc:creator: Akemi Terukina, Sakura Murakami

media:content.media:description: Traffic travels along a road as pedestrians using umbrellas walk along sidewalks in Tokyo, Japan, on Wednesday, April 1, 2020. Japan’s coronavirus numbers have been ticking up, sparking alarm that it could be the next major country to see an explosive jump in infections. It’s also raising questions about whether Tokyo is about to go into a European-style lockdown -- speculation the government is trying to squash. Photographer: Noriko Hayashi/Bloomberg

item.title: Gold Palaces, Jet Deals and McDonald’s: Trump at Home in Middle East
item.description: Donald Trump beamed from the passenger seat of a golf cart as Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman took the wheel and personally whisked the US president to a desert oasis dinner in an ancient city.
item.dc:creator: Kate Sullivan

media:content.media:description: Donald Trump and Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman during a signing ceremony at the Royal Palace, Saudi Arabia.

item.title: US Patience Running Thin on Ukraine Peace Bid
item.description: Welcome to Balance of Power, bringing you the latest in global politics. If you haven’t yet, sign up here.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Halpin

media:content.media:description: A meeting of Turkish, US and Ukrainian officials in Istanbul, on May 16. Photographer: Murat Gok/Anadolu/Getty Images

item.title: Trump’s Rush to Cut AI Deals in Saudi Arabia and UAE Opens Rift With China Hawks
item.description: President Donald Trump’s flurry of artificial intelligence deals during his tour of the Middle East is opening a rift within his own administration as China hawks grow increasingly concerned the projects are putting US national security and economic interests at risk.
item.dc:creator: Mackenzie Hawkins, Jenny Leonard

media:content.media:description: Donald Trump and Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman arrive at the Gulf Cooperation Council Leaders’ Summit in Riyadh on May 14.

item.title: Ukraine Truce Prospects Dim as Calls for New Sanctions Grow
item.description: Hopes faded for a Ukraine ceasefire after President Vladimir Putin sent a low-level delegation to talks in Turkey, while attention shifted to bids on Capitol Hill for fresh sanctions to bring the Russian leader to the negotiating table.
item.dc:creator: Natalia Drozdiak, Jamie Tarabay

media:content.media:description: Ukraine’s Andrii Sybiha, left, Lindsey Graham and Marco Rubio in Antalya, on May 15.

item.title: Trump Project Is Still on in Belgrade, Serbian President Says
item.description: Serbian President Aleksandar Vucic denied there was any snag in plans for Jared Kushner’s firm to build a luxury hotel and residences in Belgrade.
item.dc:creator: Gresa Kraja

media:content.media:description: The damaged building of the former federal military headquarters in Belgrade, which was planned for luxury hotel financed by the Trump family.

item.title: Trump Says US Will Set Tariff Rates for Other Nations in Weeks
item.description: President Donald Trump said he would set tariff rates for US trading partners “over the next two to three weeks,” saying his administration lacks the capacity to negotiate deals with all of its trading partners.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer A Dlouhy

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump, alongside Scott Bessent, left, and Howard Lutnick at the White House in February.

item.title: EU Exports to US Shot Up Just Before Trump’s ‘Liberation Day’
item.description: The European Union’s exports to the US rocketed in the month before President Donald Trump unveiled his so-called “Liberation Day” trade war with the rest of the world.
item.dc:creator: Craig Stirling

item.title: Leader of South Africa’s DA Lauds New Budget as ‘Credible’
item.description: The head of South Africa’s second-biggest political party said talks about the nation’s revamped budget “are going very, very well,” a signal that the coalition government is resolving differences that derailed the National Treasury’s previous tax and spending proposals.
item.dc:creator: Rene Vollgraaff

media:content.media:description: John Steenhuisen

item.title: Portugal’s Dueling Parties Both Want More Chinese Investments
item.description: Incumbent PSD and opposition Socialists face off on Sunday in a tight election race
item.dc:creator: Joao Lima, Henrique Almeida

media:content.media:description: The port town of Sines in southern Portugal will be home to a new lithium battery plant built by Chinese manufacturer CALB.

item.title: Qatar’s Wealth Fund Plans $500 Billion US Push Over 10 Years
item.description: During his first 15 years at Qatar Investment Authority, Mohammed Al Sowaidi helped establish its US presence and scout opportunities. Now, as head of the $524 billion state-backed entity, he’s pledging to invest an amount nearly equal to the fund’s current size, as part of a major commitment by the Gulf nation.
item.dc:creator: Fiona MacDonald, Dinesh Nair, Matthew Martin

media:content.media:description: Donald J. Trump in Doha on May 14. Photographer: Win McNamee/Getty Images

item.title: What’s the De Minimis Tariff Loophole That Trump Closed?
item.description: A Latin term that used to be little-known outside the world of customs brokers has become the stuff of headlines this year. That’s thanks to a decision by US President Donald Trump to close a tariff loophole for “de minimis” merchandise from mainland China and Hong Kong from May 2.
item.dc:creator: Brendan Murray, Samson Ellis

media:content.media:description: Packages at a neighborhood sorting center in Beijing, China.

item.title: Trump’s Pledge to Lift Syrian Sanctions Faces a Complex Road
item.description: US President Donald Trump says he’s ready to ease sanctions on Syria. He won’t be able to do it quickly.
item.dc:creator: Sam Dagher

media:content.media:description: Buildings destroyed during the war in Harasta, on the outskirts of Damascus, Syria. Photographer: David Lombeida/Bloomberg

item.title: World Economic Forum Courts Lagarde as Its Next Leader After Founder’s Abrupt Exit
item.description: Klaus Schwab’s abrupt departure from the World Economic Forum, the influential organization he founded and led for more than half a century, has complicated carefully laid plans to persuade Christine Lagarde to assume the helm in a seamless transition, according to people familiar with the discussions.
item.dc:creator: Hugo Miller, Jan-Henrik Foerster, Bastian Benrath-Wright

media:content.media:description: Christine Lagarde Photographer: Stefan Wermuth/Bloomberg

item.title: US Treasury Warns Hong Kong Banks Over Funding Iran Oil Trades
item.description: A US Treasury delegation met with Hong Kong banks to warn them against facilitating Iran oil shipments to China in April, just a month before sanctioning nine non-bank entities in the city allegedly involved in such trades, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Echo Wong, Denise Wee

media:content.media:description: An Iranian national flag flies near gas condensate processing facilities in the new Phase 3 facility at the Persian Gulf Star Co. (PGSPC) refinery in Bandar Abbas, Iran, on Wednesday, Jan. 9. 2019. The third phase of the refinery begins operations next week and will add 12-15 million liters a day of gasoline output capacity to the plant, Deputy Oil Minister Alireza Sadeghabadi told reporters. Photographer: Ali Mohammadi/Bloomberg

item.title: India’s Jaishankar Discusses Kashmir in First Call With Taliban
item.description: India’s foreign minister discussed last month’s deadly attack in Kashmir during his first conversation with Afghanistan’s Taliban-led government, as the two sides continue efforts to improve ties.
item.dc:creator: Eltaf Najafizada

media:content.media:description: Subrahmanyam Jaishankar

item.title: India Airports End Turkish Firm’s Services Over Pakistan Row
item.description: India stopped a Turkish company from operating at its airports after Turkey voiced support for Pakistan during a recent conflict between the two South Asian neighbors.
item.dc:creator: Taylan Bilgic, Mihir Mishra

media:content.media:description: An aircraft flies over Indira Gandhi International Airport in New Delhi, India, on Tuesday, Aug. 24, 2021. India plans to raise 6 trillion rupees ($81 billion) by leasing out state-owned infrastructure assets over the next four years to fund new capital expenditure without pressuring government finances. The proposal involves handing assets including roads, railways, airports, sports stadiums, power transmission lines and gas pipelines to private operators.

item.title: UK Visa Scams Squeeze Millions From Would-Be Care Workers
item.description: Recent changes to immigration policy won’t do anything for people who’ve been exploited while seeking jobs in the UK. But they may worsen the care-worker shortage.
item.dc:creator: Lucy White

media:content.media:description: Mr. Brown (left), a self-described “scammer hunter,” and his de facto bodyguard Sting.

item.title: Romania’s Destiny Rides on Trump Follower Versus Math Prodigy
item.description: Romania’s track record as a reliable supporter of the European project will be put to the test Sunday as an ultranationalist Donald Trump disciple contends for the presidency against a one-time math prodigy.
item.dc:creator: Irina Vilcu, Andra Timu

media:content.media:description: Nicusor Dan, left, and George Simion during a live election debate in Bucharest, on May 8.

item.title: Trump to Keep 30% China Tariffs Till Late 2025, Analysts Say
item.description: Donald Trump’s tariffs on China will likely remain at a level expected to severely curtail Chinese exports to the US after the 90-day truce, analysts and investors say, suggesting Beijing may have to endure further economic pain despite active talks.
item.dc:creator: Cynthia Li, Yujing Liu, Iris Ouyang

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump before signing an executive order in the Roosevelt Room of the White House in Washington, DC, US, on Monday, May 12, 2025. Trump is attempting to slash drug prices for Americans by more closely aligning their costs to lower prices paid abroad, renewing and expanding upon a failed push from his first term.

item.title: Pakistan Says Ceasefire With India to Be Extended to May 18 as Truce Holds
item.description: The ceasefire between Pakistan and India will be extended to May 18, a top official in Islamabad said, indicating the respite in fighting is holding after clashes this month brought the two nuclear-armed nations close to a full-blown war.
item.dc:creator: Khalid Qayum, Sudhi Ranjan Sen

media:content.media:description: Indian paramilitary troopers stand guard along a street in Srinagar on May 15, 2025. Pakistan's nuclear arsenal should be under the surveillance of the UN's nuclear agency, Indian Defence Minister Rajnath Singh said on May 15, following last week's four days of conflict between Islamabad and New Delhi. (Photo by Tauseef MUSTAFA / AFP) (Photo by TAUSEEF MUSTAFA/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: Britain and the EU Haunted by Old Divisions on the Road to a New Deal
item.description: In the blistering heat outside Winston Churchill’s ancestral home last summer, it began to dawn on Keir Starmer that his plan to reset Britain’s relationship with the European Union would be easier said than done.
item.dc:creator: Alex Wickham, Alberto Nardelli, Ellen Milligan, Jorge Valero

media:content.media:description: Keir Starmer, right, greets Pedro Sanchez at Blenheim Palace in Oxford last year.

item.title: Crypto Bill Poised for Resurrection After Democrats Hail Changes
item.description: Crypto-friendly Senate Democrats moved closer to reviving stablecoin legislation sought by the industry after bipartisan negotiators agreed to assorted revisions, including tightened restrictions on money laundering, foreign issuers and technology companies.
item.dc:creator: Teresa Xie, Steven T. Dennis

media:content.media:description: Senator Angela Alsobrooks, a Democrat from Maryland, speaks during a Senate Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions Committee confirmation hearing in Washington, DC, US, on Thursday, Feb. 27, 2025. Keith Sonderling has been serving as a senior adviser to the Acting Secretary of Labor Vince Micone since Trump took office last month.

item.title: Sparring Over SALT in Trump Tax Bill Threatens Fast Passage
item.description: Republican infighting in the US House is threatening to sink President Donald Trump’s legislative agenda as competing factions spar over details of the giant tax bill.
item.dc:creator: Jarrell Dillard, Emily Birnbaum, Ken Tran

media:content.media:description: Representative Jason Smith

item.title: Trump Argues Immunity in Fight With Truth Social Co-Founders
item.description: Lawyers for President Donald Trump argued to a Delaware judge that a suit against him by the co-founders of his Truth Social platform should be dismissed or put on hold because he has immunity from such litigation while in office.
item.dc:creator: Jef Feeley, Sabrina Willmer

media:content.media:description: The Truth Social logo on a laptop arranged in New York, US, on Friday, March 22, 2024. Shareholders of Digital World Acquisition Corp., a publicly traded shell company, approved a deal to merge with the Trump's media business in a Friday vote. That means Trump Media & Technology Group, whose flagship product is social networking site Truth Social, will soon begin trading on the Nasdaq stock market, reported the AP. Photographer: Gabby Jones/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump’s Cuts at Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac May Slow Housing Recovery, Report Says
item.description: The Trump administration’s cuts to Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the government-sponsored mortgage giants, may put a damper on the housing market as it becomes harder to obtain some types of home loans, according to a report from Bloomberg Intelligence.
item.dc:creator: Scott Carpenter

item.title: Tallying Up the Price for Trump’s ‘One Big, Beautiful Bill’
item.description: This is Washington Edition, the newsletter about money, power and politics in the nation’s capital. Today, senior economy reporter Enda Curran looks at the varying estimates of the cost for the Republican tax-cut bill. Sign up here and follow us at @bpolitics. Email our editors here.
item.dc:creator: Enda Curran
